The Early Game: Also Known As “Your Villain Origin Story”

You start as a guy who looks like he hasn’t eaten since the tutorial, wearing clothes that protect you from absolutely nothing.
Your first fight? You lose it.
Your second fight? You lose it harder.
Your third fight? You’re unconscious before the enemies even reach you.

And the game just stands there, watching, whispering:
“Get up, loser. We’re not done.”

Learning Skills by Suffering

In any normal RPG, you level up by doing cool things.
In Kenshi, you level up by:

Running away from every living creature → Athletics +3

Getting punched in the throat → Toughness +5

Carrying your unconscious friends around like gym bags → Strength +10

Sneaking → Actually no, you got caught, get up idiot

It’s a game that genuinely believes in character development through trauma.

Companions: The Real Burden of Leadership

You can recruit people!
But be warned: they are just as stupid as you.

Tell someone to guard the base? They’ll wander off to punch a gorilla.
Tell someone to stay inside? They’ll open the door to say hi to the bandits.

Nothing in this world fears death, and it shows.

Base Building: Where Hope Goes to Die

You dream of building a thriving settlement.
What you actually build is:

A crooked wall

A door that opens backwards

Farms that produce depression instead of food

A graveyard you add to every 45 minutes

And just when you’re feeling proud, 40 bandits show up demanding “all your money and maybe a kidney.”

Combat: The Floor Is Your Best Friend

Combat in Kenshi is deep. Tactical. Complex.
But most of the time, you’re lying on the ground watching your teammates get folded like laundry.

It’s fine, though. Being unconscious is basically the game’s version of a coffee break.

The Kenshi Experience in One Line

You start the game as prey, and after 80 hours, you finally become… slightly less edible.

Final Verdict

Kenshi is hard. It’s brutal. It’s unfair.
But once you accept that the world hates you and everything wants to kill you, it becomes one of the most strangely peaceful games ever made.

10/10.
Would get enslaved again.

[h3]Elder Scrolls?[/h3]
So imagine playing Morrowind, but the combat is not buttcheeks.
Okay now change the perspective to top down and movement to point & click.
Fights are hard? How about recruiting another person? Now you control two "protagonists", each with their own inventory to manage.

[h3]Hunger[/h3]
Oh shoot they need to eat? Yes, hunger is a game mechanic here.
It's up to you how you go about acquiring food - you can hunt, buy or steal it.
Want to add a hunter/thief to the team to deal with that? You can.
Want to just build a farm that grows the food? You can, but now the game is an RTS.
wait what

[h3]RTS?[/h3]
Yes, building a base attracts all sorts of bandits that want your food too.
And any enemies you make along the way will send attacks as well.
[i]"What if I don't care about this food and base thing, I just wanna run around and kill some dudes"[/i]
Believe it or not, you can.
Simply pick a robot as the starting race and now you can focus on fighting and exploring. 
Robots (skeleton race) don't need food to survive.
But be aware that some towns really don't like robots.

[h3]Freedom[/h3]
[i]"Oh yeah? I'm gonna wipe those towns off the map"[/i]
Here's the thing... you can.
There are no "essential" NPCs and every character can be killed.
Not without consequences of course, be ready for bounty hunters.

[h3]Leveling up & Skills[/h3]
Your skills get better based on what you do, there is no assigning points after leveling up.
Want higher movement speed? Run a lot.
Be more stealthy? Sneak around.
Want to be tougher? Fight stronger enemies, lose fights.
Unsure which weapon to use? Just use your fists and you'll become Bruce Lee eventually.
[spoiler]I'm not even kidding, you can take down entire armored platoons with a high martial arts level
[/spoiler]

[h3]Pace[/h3]
I say eventually because progressing and becoming stronger is... not fast.
It's a slow game, so make sure you're in the right mindset before playing. 
There is an option to crank the game speed to x3 for the more boring tasks like mining/crafting & travelling long distances.

[h3]Jank[/h3]
Another potential hurdle is jank. The game, to put plainly, is not polished. 
It was developed by one guy and it shows - characters get stuck, visual glitches and stutters.
Personally I enjoyed the gameplay loop enough to overlook those issues.
I recommend capping the game at 60 FPS and applying some form of frame gen for smoothness.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]
To sum up, the amount of freedom Kenshi gives you simply cannot be compared to the sandbox "freedom" of your Skyrims, your GTAs, your Minecrafts, your Witchers or your Elden Rings.
Only Rimworld comes to mind as the closest example to a game that lets you do what you want.
There is lore, there are characters you meet that have interesting stories to tell.
But there are no credits at the end because you're the one deciding the goal.

The best way to describe Kenshi is to say it feels like the child of a toxic marriage between The Sims and Dark Souls. You control one (or several) characters who have absolutely no combat skill in a vast sandbox world filled with interesting stories and a world that clearly doesn’t love you. Half the time, you feel great about the progress you’re making; the other half, you’re lying unconscious on the ground after losing a fight, waiting for your character to recover.

The game also has a spectacular modding community that greatly enhances the experience. Combat animations are surprisingly satisfying, and the world itself is genuinely interesting to explore and interact with - every character can be defeated, kidnapped, or killed, including yours.

For example, I once created a character who started as a slave. I learned how to sneak, knock out guards, steal their clothes, and escape the mines. After a long struggle, I found a small shack with food and basic supplies, which i found pretty immersive. It’s also worth mentioning that the building system is deeper and more enjoyable than it first appears, even if it can be a bit frustrating at times.

Personally, I had a lot of fun with the game, but I have to admit it involves a heavy amount of grind - leveling skills takes time and often requires tedious repetition. The game also suffers from performance issues, including occasional crashes.

My biggest disappointment came when I tried playing with a party of four characters. They just stand next to each other doing nothing unless you manually assign every task. I think the game would be far more immersive if it relied more confidently on AI to help manage (or at least give life to) your characters. I’d love to set up a camp at night and see them interact naturally.

Overall, it’s a great game, and I’m excited to see what Kenshi 2 will bring.

Kenshi has everything you could want in a great RPG: intriguing world-building and history, interesting characters with unique personalities, and the freedom to create whoever or whatever you'd like. The map is full of places to explore, and the best part is that nothing stops you from going anywhere or doing anything. Want to start a prospering colony? You can. Want to become a treasure or bounty hunter? Go for it.

For me personally, the atmosphere of the game gives me Dune/Fallout vibes, both of which I greatly love. So I would highly recommend it to anyone with similar interests.

With all that said, there's one particular thing I've come to value very much and haven't seen in many other games: the incredible amount of freedom to adjust the game to your liking. To name a few examples, there's a built-in world editor that lets you change anything you don't like, the FCS modding tool, which allows you to create your own mods or even merge characters from two different saves and play with both of them at the same time. The last one is something I've especially grown fond of.

If I had to mention one downside, it would be the amount of time I've spent playing it. But I don't regret a single minute.

In most RPGs, you are the chosen one. A hero of destiny. The Dragonborn. The world revolves around you, not in Kenshi. In Kenshi, you are a malnourished, illiterate amnesiac with one arm, no pants, and a 500 cat bounty on your head for simply existing. You are not the hero. You are not the chosen one. You are, at best, a free meal for a pack of cannibals.

Kenshi is not a video game. It's a Getting Kicked in the Groin simulator. The character creator lets you spend an hour designing your perfect martial artist, who will then spawn into the world and be immediately beaten into a coma by a hungry bandit who wants your single, stale bread roll.


The core gameplay loop of Kenshi is failing upward. You get stronger by getting your ass kicked. You learn to fight by losing fights. You learn to be a doctor by frantically trying to bandage a teammate who is bleeding from 14 different wounds at once. You learn to be a thief by getting caught, thrown in jail, and then spending three days picking the lock on your own cage while a guard periodically clubs you for fun.



Let's talk about the Beak Things. They look like a blind giraffe was cross-bred with a velociraptor and a wood chipper. They run faster than an Olympic sprinter, they hit like a freight train, and they will, without exception, eat your entire squad alive, starting with the legs.



Oh, the limb system! This is the best part. Losing a leg in Kenshi isn't a Game Over. It's an opportunity. Why keep that useless, fleshy leg when you can replace it with a high-grade, industrial-strength  robot leg that lets you run at 50 mph and kick a slaver's head clean off his shoulders? This is the only game in history where you will actively cheer when your main character's arm gets lopped off, because you've been saving up for a sweet new robot one.

The game is ugly. Let's be honest. It looks like a PlayStation 2 game that was microwaved. The UI was designed by a madman. But it doesn't matter.

You're not here for the graphics. You're here for the stories. You're here to build a fortress in the middle of nowhere, crewed entirely by one-armed skeletons who grow cactus rum, just to spite the Holy Nation. You're here to find a weird, screaming robot named Beep who thinks he's a human and train him into the single greatest swordsman the wasteland has ever known. You're here to fail, to suffer, to lose, and to eventually, after 300 hours, become a slightly-less-pathetic-than-average warlord.

It's not a game. It's an anecdote generator. An engine for hilarious, brutal, and unforgettable failure.

Kenshi is a sandbox RPG that delivers a demanding and systems-driven experience with minimal guidance. The game drops you into an indifferent world where survival depends on observation, planning, and slow skill growth. This structure creates a steady sense of earned progress rather than scripted advancement.

Its visual style is sparse but functional. Environments feel harsh and open, which matches the tone of the setting. The interface is utilitarian and prioritizes information density over aesthetics, keeping the focus on management and positioning.

Gameplay centers on squad control, long-term progression, and logistical planning. Characters improve through use rather than levels, which makes every task a long investment. Combat is slow and punishing. Success comes from preparation and smart retreat rather than direct confrontation.

The world simulation is the core strength. Factions operate independently, towns shift over time, and events unfold without player intervention. This creates a sense of persistence and scale uncommon in similar titles.

Storytelling is emergent. There is no central narrative; instead, player actions generate personal stories through survival, defeat, and rebuilding. This structure demands patience but offers unusual freedom.

Performance varies by location and squad size, yet remains stable enough for long sessions. Load times and pathfinding are imperfect but manageable given the scope of simulation.

Overall Kenshi is a methodical and unforgiving sandbox for players who value autonomy and systemic depth. It avoids cinematic design and instead provides a world that reacts, resists, and occasionally rewards persistence.

Kenshi is my favorite game.

It is a large prebuilt explorable sandbox world where you create your own story through your adventure. The game has a one of a kind atmosphere, and a large amount of freedom. You can be a trader, bandit, war band, explorer, shop, settlement, rebellion, thief, drug smuggler, hunter, bounty hunter, liberator, and more. You train your characters by doing the actions you want them to be good at, even getting beaten up you can train to get good at. You can automate jobs and actions of your squad members to keep them productive even when you aren't micromanaging. 

The game has a very unique world (Moon?) with hidden lore, ancient history, unique races, feuds and more, half of it lost and more for you to find. The game world itself is chock full of unique and wonderous fantastical locations, some even completely uninhabitable or horrifying, to say without spoiling the adventure.

For gameplay, you control the camera and often will zoom out quite far to select actions and jobs for your squad members, you do not directly control a character's actions movement, instead selecting where they move, who they follow or what jobs they do. [h1]Why is Kenshi so special?[/h1]
[h2]Freedom in Gameplay[/h2]
Kenshi is the epitome of freedom in gaming. There’s no rigid story or set objectives. You’re free to choose your path: become a trader, a mercenary, a thief, or even a ruler. The world responds dynamically to your choices, making every playthrough unique. The lack of hand-holding allows for true emergent gameplay, where your actions shape the world.

[h2]A Massive, Diverse World[/h2]
The world of Kenshi is enormous and varied, spanning hundreds of square kilometers filled with different landscapes like deserts, swamps, and ruined cities. Each region has its own atmosphere, and factions are constantly battling or trading, creating a living, evolving world. Unlike many games, Kenshi doesn’t have scripted events — the world runs its own course, regardless of what you do.

[h2]Survival and Difficulty[/h2]
This is not an easy game. Injuries, starvation, and hostile factions are just a few of the many dangers you face. There’s a heavy emphasis on survival mechanics, and losing a limb or a squad member has real consequences. The difficulty can be overwhelming at first, but it’s deeply satisfying to overcome these challenges. Progression feels earned, not handed to you.

[h2]Base-Building and Squad Management[/h2]
You can establish your own base, manage production, and recruit NPCs to help you with tasks or defend your home. The game doesn’t hold your hand in this aspect — your base and squad’s success depend on how well you manage them. It adds a great strategic layer to the game, where planning ahead is crucial for survival.

[h2]Dynamic Factions and Politics[/h2]
Kenshi features a rich tapestry of factions that each have their own goals and values. Whether it's the religious zealots of the Holy Nation or the opportunistic United Cities, each faction has its own agenda. These factions are independent of your actions, so their conflicts and relationships with each other keep the world feeling alive. You can even influence these factions, but they’ll always have their own plans.

[h2]An Indie Gem with a Rough Edge[/h2]
Kenshi was developed by a small team, with much of the work done by one man over the course of 12 years. It’s clear the game was made with a lot of passion, and its rough edges show that it wasn’t made with mainstream appeal in mind. The graphics are functional, the interface is a little clunky, and the learning curve is steep, but the depth and originality more than make up for it.

[h1]What about the modding community?[/h1]
Kenshi’s modding community is incredibly active, with a wide range of mods that enhance or completely overhaul the game. These mods can make everything from improving performance to adding new factions, locations, and game mechanics.
[list]
[*][b]Content Mods:[/b] Some mods add new items, weapons, and factions to the game, enhancing the world and gameplay. Examples include the Universal Wasteland Expansion and the Reactive World mod, which makes the world react more meaningfully to your actions.
[*][b]Visual & UI Mods:[/b] Mods like City Architecture Total Overhaul improve the look and feel of the world, while UI mods make the interface more user-friendly.
[*][b]Performance Mods:[/b] The game’s engine isn’t perfect, so mods like the Particle System Override help with performance, especially in larger, more populated areas.
[*][b]Community Tools:[/b] The developers provide modding tools like the Forgotten Construction Set, which allows modders to create their own custom content and share it with the community.
[/list]
These mods keep Kenshi fresh, even after hundreds of hours of gameplay. Whether you’re looking to enhance the visuals, tweak gameplay mechanics, or overhaul the entire experience, there’s a mod for that. Plus, it’s clear that the modding community has a deep love for the game, making Kenshi feel like an ever-evolving experience.

[h1]Why It’s Worth Playing[/h1]
In the end, Kenshi stands out because of its depth, freedom, and the feeling of being part of a chaotic world. It's not a game that guides you, but instead gives you the tools to create your own story. The modding community ensures that the game remains exciting long after the main experience ends, providing new ways to enjoy it. If you’re looking for a hardcore survival game with an immense, open world and plenty of challenges, Kenshi delivers in spades.

This game is... something. 

Usually, I write reviews as a way to summarize my experience, from the beginning to the end, after I'm either finished or decided that I'm done with a game.

But with Kenshi, I'm a bit at a loss for words. I don't know where to start or finish, and I guess that's a pretty good analogy for the game itself.

It's an open sandbox that pretends to be RPG, while having no real story, quests, meaningful interactions with NPCs (other than imprisoning them) or even proper ability to build your character with feats, perks and the like, rather you just level up your skills by doing stuff. And it's a grind. Terrible, slow, boring grind where you can simply leave your characters AFK running circles to level up movement speed & STR.

So it's not a proper RPG, similar to Dragon Age Origins, Mass Effect, Gothic, Elder Scrolls, SWKOTOR and the like.

It's not an RTS either, though you could be fooled by the way the game presents itself. But Kenshi has rather small limit of NPC you can control and a pretty low limit on how many attackers can attack at a time, so any character gets time to parry all the attacks NPCs land on them. Most attacks also have AoE dmg, which is unavoidable - you can't dodge or block, if you're not the main target of the attack. 

You can't exactly make them to walk in formations. Pathfinding couldn't find its path to the game, so you have to do a lot of micro. 

Basebuilding is also bad - from bad slopping and problems with placing objects (or weird angles) to terrible optimization, and small character limit, which - all combined - makes building a big base inpractical at best.  

What's worse, no NPCs will ever try to settle/join your base. You also can't sell stuff by creating your own shops, because NPCs don't have enough money to buy anything slightlty expensvie - hell, you can even see that in bars, when NPCs just come in, say "it's too expensive" and leave. 

On a side note, you can't build anything too close to cities. But I once build a wall on a neutral territory, and a small part of it became property of a faction. Which also lead to them trying to get me to pay the tribute, because the game also won't tell you if you're buidling within factions' borders or not.

So yeah, lots of bugs. Lackluster RPG and RTS elements, terrible grind.

How much time did I spend in the game? 172 hours. Why? Honestly, I don't know. 

It's a new type of game for me with an interesting concept. The one, where failure doesn't mean that the game ends.
Most NPCs can't kill you (other than cannibal-type and some robots, which will either eat you alive, or skin you alive to make a human-skin clothing), and neither can you. 

There are work-arounds and expections (for animals), but generally you can't execute anyone.

Which leads to a main sellling point of the game (in my opinion):

There's always a way to turn things around without reloading save, which was kind of counter-intuitive for me, but lead to a lot of interesting situations due to random generation of various stuff.

The game also has a nice concept of world states, where killing or imprisoning NPCs leads to actual changes in the world.

And a ton of cool mods that make it way more interesting, enjoyable and over all add worldstates and other stuff.

The only problem is, once you go through the gring and start winning, the game kind of doesn't have a lot to offer.

The main point of the game and its gameplay loop is overcoming the odds - which are not in your favor - through suffering(grind) and various shennenigans. Once you've leveled up several characters and got good equipement, the game is basically over. Without the challenge and difficulties, the game is empty and can't offer anything, other than lackluster base buidling.

You can "paint" the map, see all the world states and etc, but it felt more like going through check list, rather than actually playing and/or enjoying the game.

By the time you properly level up, the game is over. And it kind of sucks there are no really big events for end game.
Come to think of it, it's actually the theme of the game - it throws interesting concepts at you, but never bothers to properly and fully develop them.

So, is Kenshi a bad or a good game? Do I recommend it or not?

An answer to the former would be "it's a niche". If you like the "failure is not the end" mindset and ok with your bad choices mixed with RNG creating your own story, then you'll probably like this game. Just do yourself a favor and istall mod collection from a guy, who made it for himself and his wife. It's one of the top mod collections (if not the top-one) in the workshop, has Vanilla+ feeling and fixes a lot of bugs and exploits. Do not do Vanilla run, you won't miss on anything.

If that doesn't sound fun to you, then avoid it like a fire. The game will feel too grindy, unpolished and buggy, which it actually is.

As for the latter, I'm on the fence. I enjoyed my time (to a point) with the game, and the price is quite low even without the discount. But I mostly did so, because I played with mods.  

If I'd have to play the Vanilla game - or mod it by hand, as opposed to using collections and copy-pasting mod order - I wouldn't have enjoyed it as much as I did.

And if the game is no fun without mods, I have to go with a "no", I don't recommend the game.

But if some of the concepts I mentioned sounded fun to you, and you don't mind the mods, buy it at a discount, install top-rated collection and give it a try. You might suprise yourself, just as I did.

But if you are not willing to suffer in order to enjoy all that suffering, you will have to make peace with how broken it is. Here are some of the things that are deeply unfortunate:
- The game crashes every now and then. The quick save shortcut is your friend.
- Path finding is broken
- If someone mans a turret, they won't leave to eat and just stand there starving unless you micro manage their food
- Enemies clipping right through your fortified gates
- A building system that functions only worse than it looks. For instance, you can build something there now, but in a while it will show up as being too close to a town. Or you build a wall on a slope and gaps underneath allow enemies to just stroll in
- Sometimes an animal won't eat. It will just stand there, starve and die. The game does not notify you when one of your faction is starving.
- There is a lot of ground to cover, and loading screens cause bad stuttering
- There is a lot of topography, but the building system only really works well on flat ground
- Game is pretty ugly 
- The pathfinding has lots of issues. You might see that some work is not being done because someone can't find a path to the work or they are stuck in a patch where the pathfinding can't get them out.
- Clipping and getting stuck in walls
- A trader comes to town. They will leave while you are busy trading with them.

Despite all of this, it is a great game in my opinion. But if you aren't willing to take it warts and all I would recommend waiting for Kenshi 2. If you do decide to take the pain, mods are essential and not as likely to break as in some other games.
